docs.lead_paragraph: In a grand leap of logic about 100 years ago, doctors pinpointed the cause of violent crime, suicide, nervous exhaustion, insomnia, fatigue, headaches, confusion, sexual dysfunction, bad skin, baldness, tuberculosis, gum disease, cancer and spinsterhood. The culprit was intestinal stasis, leading to that horror of horrors, autointoxication. It was, please pardon the term, constipation. And it was universal. Astute doctors could spot victims everywhere, even on city streets, by their telltale greasy skins and septic open mouths. Autointoxication meant that toxins from backed-up, rotting wastes were seeping into their bloodstreams, poisoning their bodies and minds. They needed help. They needed cleaning out. They needed laxatives, roughage, special exercises, trusses, gut-pounding massages, abdominal vibrating machines and a menacing array of equipment to administer ''internal baths'' and restore muscle tone to their flaccid innards. Sometimes, they needed drastic surgery to rearrange their insides.

docs.lead_paragraph: With high-carbohydrate foods getting such a bad rap, it is refreshing to hear about new findings that clearly demonstrate the health value of a carbohydrate-rich diet, as long as it contains the right carbohydrates, replete with soluble and insoluble fiber, the way nature made them. Fiber has also been knocked around a bit lately, after three disappointing studies failed to find that a high-fiber diet helped to prevent colon cancer. If preventing colon cancer was the only reason to eat fiber, I would say you could safely abandon bran muffins, whole-grain cereals, beans and peas and fiber-rich fruits and vegetables and return to a pristine diet of pasty white bread. But dietary fiber, as the new study so graphically showed, has myriad health benefits. The study also shows that people need not resort to a very low-fat diet to reap those benefits, as long as the fat in their diets is also the right kind.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Cybersex Gives Birth to a Psychological Disorder'' and ''First Step Is Recognizing the Signs of Internet Abuse'' on May 16 alert the reader to the dangerous similarities between compulsive cybersex and drug addiction. Yet the articles would read about the same after one substituted for ''cybersex'' the word ''golf.'' Both activities, for example, can easily meet the quoted definition of an addiction: ''Loss of control, continuation of the behavior despite significant adverse consequences and preoccupation with obtaining the drug (or tee time) or pursuing the behavior (or whacking the ball).''

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As a postscript to ''As Mount St. Helens Recovers, Old Wisdom Crumbles'' (May 16), it's worth noting that the National Volcanic Monument is just a few hours from either Seattle or Portland. The sights encountered there rival the Grand Canyon and Meteor Crater in Arizona as examples of nature's power to alter our planet on a vast scale. Mount St. Helens is the experience of a lifetime, and it's a wonderful antidote to too many theme parks. ARTHUR E. LANDAU Las Vegas

docs.lead_paragraph: J. Carol Goodman, a 71-year-old writer from Morristown, N.J., was hiking in the Swiss Alps four years ago when she became dizzy, lost her sense of balance and began, as she put it, walking like a drunk. She managed to get back to her friends' home in St. Moritz and went to bed. ''I woke the next morning with the room spinning,'' she recalled. After she began vomiting, she was taken by ambulance to a nearby hospital.
docs.abstract: Accusations fly in long-simmering debate over treating Lyme disease; one camp of doctors holds that most cases of Lyme can be successfully treated within 30 to 60 days of antibiotics and that if symptoms continue, they are due to something other than the Lyme spirochete and will not be helped by further use of antibiotics; another camp holds that patients suffering long-term symptoms need long-term antibiotic treatment; both Allen C Steers, who is of the first group, and Dr Joseph J Burrascano, who is of the second group, have been ordered by their states' medical boards to answer formal complaints about their practices; patients with chronic symptoms are increasingly angry, vocal and organized, and members of Congress are entering the fray; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Reducing medical costs has become a major goal in the age of managed care, but a new study finds that can be trickier to accomplish than it may seem. One of the main ways to reduce costs is by shortening as much as possible the amount of time people are hospitalized. They are now told to come in as close to surgery as possible, for example, and discharged far earlier than was the practice in the past.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Thomas A. Mattioni treats patients for heart disease, so he takes no position on whether the alternative-medical practice of sleeping on magnets has any effect on arthritis or other joint diseases. But Dr. Mattioni does have a warning for those using the magnets who also have implantable pacemakers or similar devices called cardioverter defibrillator: be careful. The magnets, usually placed in mattress pads, can change the settings on the pacemakers and turn off the defibrillators -- with potentially fatal results.

docs.lead_paragraph: In quitting the Senate race last week, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani discovered that choosing a therapy for prostate cancer was a far more daunting effort than he had expected. Mr. Giuliani said he had to focus entirely on the decision, letting his immediate political future fall by the wayside. Mr. Giuliani's difficulties spring largely from a radical change in the relationship between patients and their doctors. Americans have traded in paternalism for medical consumerism after fighting for a greater voice in making critical decisions about their care. That has not come without cost.

docs.lead_paragraph: Putting infants on their backs when they go to sleep is a widely accepted technique for reducing the risk of sudden infant death syndrome, but doctors need to do a lot more to get the word out, a new study finds. Forty-one percent of parents and baby sitters surveyed reported that their babies' doctors had not told them how to put the children down to sleep, say researchers for the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development.
